{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3114773,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-30T16:16:03.560Z","cooked":"

In the 2020 Command-based rewrite, a new syntax for defining commands was added that utilizes inline function definitions (sometimes called “lambda expressions”) to define command implementation without needing to write an explicit subclass of Command. This can save a substantial amount of code overhead compared to the “traditional” method of interacting with the API via subclassing, at the cost of requiring some language syntax that (bafflingly…) is usually omitted from high-school-level programming curriculum.

While this alternate command definition syntax was originally described as a “convenience feature,” the flexibility of functional programming patterns (and continued development work from a number of volunteers!) has made the associated callback-based Command composition API extremely powerful in the following years, to the point where “traditional” subclassing-based Command definition is almost never strictly necessary.

Given these developments, in 2023 WPILib has updated the standard Command-based starter template to include examples of inline command definitions, and the newest example Command-based robot uses inline Command definitions exclusively.

These patterns are concise, expressive, and easily-readable. However, they are quite far from the organizational principles taught in most intro-level programming courses. There are some lingering concerns that this may be difficult for teams to learn or adopt, even with recent improvements to the associated Command-based documentation.

Admittedly, Chief Delphi is not a representative sampling of teams, but I think it’s still a good idea to try to get some read on where the community is with respect to these new developments. So…

How does your team primarily utilize the Command-based framework?

  • Subclassing Command
  • Defining commands inline

0 voters

Further elaboration is encouraged below. If there are any resources you think we should provide to help teams utilize these features, please share them. If there are any worries you have about migrating the recommended Command-based usage pattern to a functional rather than object-oriented paradigm, please share those too (though, to be fully transparent: it is unlikely that we will refocus the API back towards object-oriented patterns, because they are verbose and extremely rigid).

Further elaboration is encouraged below. If there are any resources you think we should provide to help teams utilize these features, please share them.

Even though frc-docs is strictly against teaching languages (which I really disagree with), a page on explaining lambda expressions (since it isn’t in APCSA) would be very helpful.

Personally, my team loves the inline approach to commands, and got a lot of use out of the recent Organizing Command-Based Robot Projects — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation linked above.

This could be a stretch, but maybe it would be a cool idea to easily provide options? Maybe on the documentation page regarding the creation of commands, you can have a tab that shows them a typical subclass approach or the inline approach.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":82,"updated_at":"2022-12-30T16:45:21.624Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":634,"readers_count":633,"score":221.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":420379,"topic_slug":"functional-programming-command-based-and-you","display_username":"Warren Yun","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/latest/docs/software/commandbased/organizing-command-based.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Organizing Command-Based Robot Projects — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":101}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52486,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1155 Alum"},"post_url":"/t/functional-programming-command-based-and-you/420379/3","custom_user_title":"1155 Alum","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3114783,"name":"","username":"IanSzalai","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ianszalai/{size}/210636_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-30T16:45:40.665Z","cooked":"

Our team has found that inline commands are an extremely useful time save, but when the command gets beyond just calling a method with a parameter or two, the readability drops quite a bit and a traditional command is better.

That being said, if you write your subsystem methods with inline commands in mind, can counteract this.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":82,"updated_at":"2022-12-30T20:13:55.446Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":602,"readers_count":601,"score":420.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":420379,"topic_slug":"functional-programming-command-based-and-you","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":19}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49699,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3255A"},"post_url":"/t/functional-programming-command-based-and-you/420379/4","custom_user_title":"3255A","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":19}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":19,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3114789,"name":"kgzak","username":"kgzak","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kgzak/{size}/157079_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-30T16:48:29.420Z","cooked":"

We have mostly done subclasses commands but will probably switch to inline commands mostly this season. It’s mainly been that the team was more familiar with sub classing than inline.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":82,"updated_at":"2022-12-30T16:48:29.420Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":547,"readers_count":546,"score":109.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":420379,"topic_slug":"functional-programming-command-based-and-you","display_username":"kgzak","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":11043,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/functional-programming-command-based-and-you/420379/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3114791,"name":"vargoose84","username":"vargoose84","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/vargoose84/{size}/165453_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-30T17:01:51.368Z","cooked":"

We were a timed robot team in 2022. Our code became complex enough where we were running mini state machines for our climber, indexer, auto, and shooter. In prior years we were a timed robot only type of team, but I’m 2022 we realized we were basically doing a poor man’s version of command based.

That’s why, this year, we will be switching over to command based. Looking over the different styles of command based, to me subclassing commands (at least the simple command like drive train commands) adds unnecessary verbosity.

Even though inlining commands can add some weird syntax (lambdas and method referencing), once you can get over the new symbols, inlined commands enumerated in robot container seems to be the most reasonable and teachable approach to robot programming.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":82,"updated_at":"2022-12-30T17:04:19.038Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":538,"readers_count":537,"score":137.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":420379,"topic_slug":"functional-programming-command-based-and-you","display_username":"vargoose84","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":30247,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3630 Assistant Coach - Stampede Robotics"},"post_url":"/t/functional-programming-command-based-and-you/420379/6","custom_user_title":"3630 Assistant Coach - Stampede Robotics","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3114800,"name":"Bryn Dole - programming mentor FRC 2930","username":"randomstring","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/randomstring/{size}/170695_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-30T17:28:30.638Z","cooked":"

Our team uses both methods.

More complicated commands, ones with more than one of initialize(), execute(), isFinished() and end() defined get a subclassed command.

Simple one shot commands that would typically only have the initialize() method defined tend to get inline definitions. Using inline commands is how we most frequently prototype commands. Sometimes the inline commands get pretty messy with all the decorators and some should probably be turned into a subclass for clarity (and some do).

I did panic a little when lambda expressions were introduced: “How am I going to teach and explain this?” It turned out not to be a big deal. I love how the value suppliers simplify commands requiring joystick input.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":82,"updated_at":"2022-12-30T17:28:30.638Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":27,"reads":505,"readers_count":504,"score":581.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":420379,"topic_slug":"functional-programming-command-based-and-you","display_username":"Bryn Dole - programming mentor FRC 2930","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":23}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33397,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/functional-programming-command-based-and-you/420379/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":23}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":23,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3114805,"name":"","username":"DeltaDizzy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/deltadizzy/{size}/170886_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-30T17:49:55.300Z","cooked":"

In 2022 (our first year using command-based), we used almost entirely inline commands. The only exceptions were subclassed command groups when we needed a very specific sequence of actions initiated by a trigger (e.g. autos, running our shoot sequence, turret homing, etc.) or the turret slewing command which could have easily been inlined by making the contents of its execute() method a subsystem method instead. If anything, I feel like the most valuable additional documented topics would be lambdas/method references and suppliers.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":82,"updated_at":"2022-12-30T17:49:55.300Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":468,"readers_count":467,"score":138.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":420379,"topic_slug":"functional-programming-command-based-and-you","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":45487,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"DataLog Hoarder"},"post_url":"/t/functional-programming-command-based-and-you/420379/8","custom_user_title":"DataLog Hoarder","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3114814,"name":"Jonah Bonner","username":"jonahb55","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jonahb55/{size}/194474_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-30T18:16:34.979Z","cooked":"

I think that inline commands are very compelling. We (6328) are already using them extensively to simplify button bindings, and I expect we will depend on them even more in 2023. For example, I’m excited about the idea of generating autos with factories where waypoints/constants are centralized in a single class. We may also experiment with command factories in simple subsystems or for those that already take advantage of sequencing with command groups (e.g. climbers). However…

I think subclassed commands can still be appropriate where the command is the controller. Command factories tend to encourage a pattern where all controllers should live in the subsystem, which I don’t think is optimal for many subsystems. Where a logical hierarchy exists between controllers in subsystems (which are always/mostly running) and controllers in commands (which only apply to one control mode), it can produce code that is far more maintainable/extendible.

For example, a drive subsystem that only accepts a set of chassis speeds (or equivalent) can be used by a default joystick-drive command, a trajectory follower command, or a variety of driver assist commands. Velocity feedfoward/feedback controllers, kinematics, odometry, etc. can live in the subsystem because they apply to all modes, but the joystick algorithm, trajectory controller, angle PID controllers, etc. can be isolated. In our experience, each drive command is often complex enough that having a separate file is far cleaner than trying to a) force that complexity into a command factory or b) turn the drive subsystem into a massive state machine. Using subclasses in this case makes it easier to add functionality later or remove a control mode we’re no longer using.

The same thing applies to a flywheel that accepts a setpoint and can use presets or auto-set speeds (two commands) or an elevator that accepts a target height and can use a joystick or presets for control. It doesn’t work for every subsystem, but this is still a structure that we plan on using where it makes sense. Otherwise, we’ll go with a more inline approach.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":82,"updated_at":"2022-12-30T18:16:34.979Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":10,"reads":453,"readers_count":452,"score":250.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":420379,"topic_slug":"functional-programming-command-based-and-you","display_username":"Jonah Bonner","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44471,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6328M/WPILib"},"post_url":"/t/functional-programming-command-based-and-you/420379/9","custom_user_title":"6328M/WPILib","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":7}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3114816,"name":"Weaver Goldman","username":"GoldMonster","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/goldmonster/{size}/154153_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-30T18:25:30.520Z","cooked":"

It also depends on preference. To keep things simple when making commands and complex behaviors, we keep most of the complex logic in our subsystems so that commands can be inline or just a basic function that calls methods from one or more subsystems.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":82,"updated_at":"2022-12-30T18:25:30.520Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":392,"readers_count":391,"score":103.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":420379,"topic_slug":"functional-programming-command-based-and-you","display_username":"Weaver Goldman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":44471,"username":"jonahb55","name":"Jonah Bonner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jonahb55/{size}/194474_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48298,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Calvin and Hobbes connoisseur"},"post_url":"/t/functional-programming-command-based-and-you/420379/10","custom_user_title":"Calvin and Hobbes connoisseur","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3114818,"name":"Izzy Haladjian","username":"izzymaria3175","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/izzymaria3175/{size}/208341_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-30T18:36:47.737Z","cooked":"

Similar to a few others who have already posted, we use a mix of subclassing commands and inline commands. I originally started with exclusively subclassing commands for consistency, but it eventually became too cumbersome to create a full class for a method like feeder.run(). I am very excited to work with command factory methods and I’m looking forward to how clean command code is going to become. I really appreciate how the docs explain the rationale behind the two and I think they do a great job of encouraging readability and consistency.

I also want to second the request for a short explanation of lambdas and inline commands. I have worked through several Java classes to try to find the best one for training new programmers, and none of them teach lambdas at all because it’s such a complex subject for beginners to understand. I understand that frc-docs avoids teaching languages, but I think this is something important to have because it’s much more difficult to find a teaching resource for it and it’s not taught in most high school CS classes.

Finally, I agree that if inline commands are to be used, the bulk of the logic should be kept in the subsystem. A quick explanation on when it is better to use inline commands vs subclass commands, or a recommendation to store logic in a certain place based on the type of command declaration may be helpful.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":82,"updated_at":"2022-12-30T18:36:47.737Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":393,"readers_count":392,"score":113.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":420379,"topic_slug":"functional-programming-command-based-and-you","display_username":"Izzy Haladjian","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49278,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3175 Alum"},"post_url":"/t/functional-programming-command-based-and-you/420379/11","custom_user_title":"3175 Alum","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3114819,"name":"Paul Rensing","username":"prensing","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/prensing/{size}/65820_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-30T18:40:29.480Z","cooked":"

We are still mostly using the subclassing method.

Honestly, I frequently find the inline code hard to read. Even the simple examples in the WPI example take some effort to understand the logic (eg Shooter.shootCommand) which I suspect would be much easier if laid out in a real method. And from what I see, many of our commands quickly evolve into much more complicate “state machines”, with timers and different test conditions. Maybe we could implement those as a series of commands (sequential, conditional etc), but I don’t see that being easier to read and understand.

So, I am with the “both” camp. The inline is fine for commands with little logic and 1-2 inputs, but I find the subclassing easier when the commands get more complex.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":82,"updated_at":"2022-12-30T18:40:29.480Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":10,"reads":359,"readers_count":358,"score":141.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":420379,"topic_slug":"functional-programming-command-based-and-you","display_username":"Paul Rensing","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25118,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 2877 LigerBots Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/functional-programming-command-based-and-you/420379/12","custom_user_title":"FRC 2877 LigerBots Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3114820,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-30T18:43:08.973Z","cooked":"
prensing:

Maybe we could implement those as a series of commands (sequential, conditional etc), but I don’t see that being easier to read and understand.

Give it a shot, and I think you’ll be surprised. A lot of the state machine work you’re doing manually with timers is almost certainly duplicated; the benefit of instead representing it with composition is that the independent pieces of the functionality can be re-combined in other ways without rewriting the same code.

You could achieve the same thing in the object-oriented model by abstracting out a superclass, but this is very verbose and imposes some rather strict conditions on the compositional structure.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":82,"updated_at":"2022-12-30T18:43:25.808Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":350,"readers_count":349,"score":90.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":420379,"topic_slug":"functional-programming-command-based-and-you","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/functional-programming-command-based-and-you/420379/13","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3114822,"name":"Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)","username":"ngreen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ngreen/{size}/264478_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-30T18:47:04.763Z","cooked":"

We also used a mixture, and that was one thing being worked on to update the last year’s robot over to more command factories. At times some of it has shifted in unexpected ways, like how some of the parallel commands changed a couple beta releases ago, but once it is more stable getting more familiar with using the convenience features I think will be well used this season. So some of that I’m still re-learning structure. We started from the RR example to write more from the bottom up, and it was helpful to show students.

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":82,"updated_at":"2022-12-30T18:47:04.763Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":338,"readers_count":337,"score":77.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":420379,"topic_slug":"functional-programming-command-based-and-you","display_username":"Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":2695,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/functional-programming-command-based-and-you/420379/14","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3114823,"name":null,"username":"anon37142155","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/f08c70/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-12-30T18:47:49.139Z","cooked":"

I’m mainly a fan of subclassing commands (although it does makes the commands folder quite thick), I think the main benefit is that you can add a lot more logic inside of a subclassed command compared to a inline command. This ultimately depends on your code structure, as I’ve seen some teams have a state machine for shooting, so therefor they can just use an inline
shooter.setShooting() where the method would set the internal state machine to the Shooting state inside of the subsystem, instead of having the logic processing inside of the subclassed command.

Personally, I’m starting to lean towards doing it this method instead of subclassing commands, but I think that our team will still use both.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":82,"updated_at":"2022-12-30T18:48:19.258Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":336,"readers_count":335,"score":72.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":420379,"topic_slug":"functional-programming-command-based-and-you","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51083,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/functional-programming-command-based-and-you/420379/15","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3114832,"name":"gcschmit","username":"gcschmit","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gcschmit/{size}/5380_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-30T20:38:08.264Z","cooked":"

We use InstantCommand when possible and subclass CommandBase when we need to override initialize, isFinished, or end. We are comfortable with this approach since it minimizes the boilerplate in CommandBase subclasses that only need to invoke another method. I think the software team members find the visual layout in the code of using the command composition classes helpful as it maps to the flowcharts that they often create.

For example, here is a example from last year’s robot code:

joystickButtons1[1].toggleWhenPressed(
        new ConditionalCommand(
            new ParallelCommandGroup(
                new InstantCommand(() -> collector.disableCollector(), collector),
                new InstantCommand(() -> storage.disableStorage(), storage),
                new InstantCommand(() -> flywheel.stopFlywheel(), flywheel)),
            new SequentialCommandGroup(
                new InstantCommand(() -> collector.enableCollector(), collector),
                new SortStorageCommand(storage),
                new InstantCommand(() -> collector.disableCollector(), collector),
                new SetFlywheelVelocityCommand(flywheel, FlywheelConstants.WALL_SHOT_VELOCITY)),
            collector::isEnabled));

Since most members have completed or are concurrently enrolled in AP Computer Science A, they are most familiar and comfortable with this approach as opposed to the more functional programming model.

Another motivation is that this combination of composite commands, instance commands, and our own commands covers the simplest to the most complicated application. New members can learn this one approach and apply it anywhere.

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":82,"updated_at":"2022-12-30T20:38:08.264Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":337,"readers_count":336,"score":122.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":420379,"topic_slug":"functional-programming-command-based-and-you","display_username":"gcschmit","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15922,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 3061 Lead Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/functional-programming-command-based-and-you/420379/16","custom_user_title":"FRC 3061 Lead Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3114833,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-30T20:42:18.599Z","cooked":"

Note that in 2023 you can remove some of Java’s new clutter by using the static factories defined in WPILibJ/Command/Commands (e.g. runOnce() instead of new InstantCommand(), or parallel() instead of new ParallelCommandGroup()). Your declaration structure would stay identical; the static factories just sugar the constructor calls for readability.

P.S. import static is your friend for writing readable Java. It’s a powerful tool, and you need to learn to use it right, but it is very helpful for keeping a check on the language’s tendency to explode in character count.

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":82,"updated_at":"2022-12-30T20:55:11.695Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":16,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":322,"readers_count":321,"score":249.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":420379,"topic_slug":"functional-programming-command-based-and-you","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":15922,"username":"gcschmit","name":"gcschmit","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gcschmit/{size}/5380_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":11}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/functional-programming-command-based-and-you/420379/17","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":9},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"hugs","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":11,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3114844,"name":"Matt Soucy (he/him)","username":"msoucy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/msoucy/{size}/237623_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-30T21:31:11.039Z","cooked":"

166 has been using inline commands in some form since 2018, starting with using Java’s anonymous classes to fill out the entire class. We were inspired by the short lived C# port, to add some early support for more inline functionality, including injecting the subsystem into the command on construction, and adding the original Instant Command support that took a lambda.

At this point, we as mentors don’t even teach that commands can be separate classes. If someone asked (which they never have) we’d probably tell them that it’s possible but the inline ones do almost everything we’d need. Even in cases where the command itself needs state, we use anonymous derived classes while retaining the “factory method” paradigm. For us, we try to teach that the main way of interacting with a subsystem is through the commands. When there isn’t a command or helper that does the main functionality we need, we do write our own.

It’s been good to see the command model evolve and grow over the past few years to support this mentality more.

Rensing","username":"prensing","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/prensing/{size}/65820_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-30T21:37:10.096Z","cooked":"

Yes, I get it, at least partly. But what I missed in my description is that, after the first few obvious commands like “drive” and “run intake”, all the interesting commands involve 2-3 subsystems and, even more challenging, have data values which need to go from one subcommand to another during the command.

So, for a simple example, a shooting command will first run the vision system to get a target lock, then feed the (conditioned?) angle to the drivetrain to turn to the target, and the distance to the shooter to set the speed. I really don’t see a clean way to move that data around from one command to another while running, apart from stashing it in a subsystem (which feels ugly), or having the subsequent commands re-fetch/compute values (which might be in different state!). Is there a clean example which does this kind of stateful progression?

I’m pretty sure that this is inline commanding but I’m not certain. It isn’t quite what is in the command-based template, but this is what I use for button commands:

public StartEndCommand clawdownCommand = new StartEndCommand(
    () -> arm.runarm(0.2),
    () -> arm.stoparm(),
  arm);
